author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Mr. Sherlock Holmes, who was usually very late in the mornings, save upon those not infrequent occasions when he was up all night, was seated at the breakfast table. I stood upon the hearth-rug and picked up the stick which our visitor had left behind him the night before. It was a fine, thick piece of wood, bulbous-headed, of the sort which is known as a "Penang lawyer.

next.content: " Just under the head was a broad silver band nearly an inch across. "To James Mortimer, M.R.C.S., from his friends of the C.C.H.," was engraved upon it, with the date "1884." It was just such a stick as the old-fashioned family practitioner used to carry—dignified, solid, and reassuring.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: " Just under the head was a broad silver band nearly an inch across. "To James Mortimer, M.R.C.S., from his friends of the C.C.H.," was engraved upon it, with the date "1884." It was just such a stick as the old-fashioned family practitioner used to carry—dignified, solid, and reassuring.

next.content: "Well, Watson, what do you make of it?"

content: "Well, Watson, what do you make of it?"

next.content: Holmes was sitting with his back to me, and I had given him no sign of my occupation.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Holmes was sitting with his back to me, and I had given him no sign of my occupation.

next.content: "How did you know what I was doing? I believe you have eyes in the back of your head."

previous.content: "Well, Watson, what do you make of it?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "How did you know what I was doing? I believe you have eyes in the back of your head."

next.content: "I have, at least, a well-polished, silver-plated coffee-pot in front of me," said he. "But, tell me, Watson, what do you make of our visitor's stick? Since we have been so unfortunate as to miss him and have no notion of his errand, this accidental souvenir becomes of importance. Let me hear you reconstruct the man by an examination of it.

previous.content: Holmes was sitting with his back to me, and I had given him no sign of my occupation.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I have, at least, a well-polished, silver-plated coffee-pot in front of me," said he. "But, tell me, Watson, what do you make of our visitor's stick? Since we have been so unfortunate as to miss him and have no notion of his errand, this accidental souvenir becomes of importance. Let me hear you reconstruct the man by an examination of it.

previous.content: "How did you know what I was doing? I believe you have eyes in the back of your head."

next.content: "I think," said I, following as far as I could the methods of my companion, "that Dr. Mortimer is a successful, elderly medical man, well-esteemed since those who know him give him this mark of their appreciation."

previous.content: "I have, at least, a well-polished, silver-plated coffee-pot in front of me," said he. "But, tell me, Watson, what do you make of our visitor's stick? Since we have been so unfortunate as to miss him and have no notion of his errand, this accidental souvenir becomes of importance. Let me hear you reconstruct the man by an examination of it.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I think," said I, following as far as I could the methods of my companion, "that Dr. Mortimer is a successful, elderly medical man, well-esteemed since those who know him give him this mark of their appreciation."

next.content: "Good!" said Holmes. "Excellent!"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Good!" said Holmes. "Excellent!"

next.content: "I think also that the probability is in favour of his being a country practitioner who does a great deal of his visiting on foot."

previous.content: "I think," said I, following as far as I could the methods of my companion, "that Dr. Mortimer is a successful, elderly medical man, well-esteemed since those who know him give him this mark of their appreciation."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I think also that the probability is in favour of his being a country practitioner who does a great deal of his visiting on foot."

next.content: "Why so?"

previous.content: "Good!" said Holmes. "Excellent!"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Why so?"

next.content: "Because this stick, though originally a very handsome one has been so knocked about that I can hardly imagine a town practitioner carrying it. The thick-iron ferrule is worn down, so it is evident that he has done a great amount of walking with it."

previous.content: "I think also that the probability is in favour of his being a country practitioner who does a great deal of his visiting on foot."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Because this stick, though originally a very handsome one has been so knocked about that I can hardly imagine a town practitioner carrying it. The thick-iron ferrule is worn down, so it is evident that he has done a great amount of walking with it."

next.content: "Perfectly sound!" said Holmes.

previous.content: "Why so?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Perfectly sound!" said Holmes.

next.content: "And then again, there is the 'friends of the C.C.H.' I should guess that to be the Something Hunt, the local hunt to whose members he has possibly given some surgical assistance, and which has made him a small presentation in return."

previous.content: "Because this stick, though originally a very handsome one has been so knocked about that I can hardly imagine a town practitioner carrying it. The thick-iron ferrule is worn down, so it is evident that he has done a great amount of walking with it."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "And then again, there is the 'friends of the C.C.H.' I should guess that to be the Something Hunt, the local hunt to whose members he has possibly given some surgical assistance, and which has made him a small presentation in return."

next.content: "Really, Watson, you excel yourself," said Holmes, pushing back his chair and lighting a cigarette. "I am bound to say that in all the accounts which you have been so good as to give of my own small achievements you have habitually underrated your own abilities. It may be that you are not yourself luminous, but you are a conductor of light.

previous.content: "Perfectly sound!" said Holmes.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Really, Watson, you excel yourself," said Holmes, pushing back his chair and lighting a cigarette. "I am bound to say that in all the accounts which you have been so good as to give of my own small achievements you have habitually underrated your own abilities. It may be that you are not yourself luminous, but you are a conductor of light.

next.content: Some people without possessing genius have a remarkable power of stimulating it. I confess, my dear fellow, that I am very much in your debt."

previous.content: "And then again, there is the 'friends of the C.C.H.' I should guess that to be the Something Hunt, the local hunt to whose members he has possibly given some surgical assistance, and which has made him a small presentation in return."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Some people without possessing genius have a remarkable power of stimulating it. I confess, my dear fellow, that I am very much in your debt."

next.content: He had never said as much before, and I must admit that his words gave me keen pleasure, for I had often been piqued by his indifference to my admiration and to the attempts which I had made to give publicity to his methods. I was proud, too, to think that I had so far mastered his system as to apply it in a way which earned his approval.

previous.content: "Really, Watson, you excel yourself," said Holmes, pushing back his chair and lighting a cigarette. It may be that you are not yourself luminous, but you are a conductor of light.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: He had never said as much before, and I must admit that his words gave me keen pleasure, for I had often been piqued by his indifference to my admiration and to the attempts which I had made to give publicity to his methods. I was proud, too, to think that I had so far mastered his system as to apply it in a way which earned his approval.

next.content: He now took the stick from my hands and examined it for a few minutes with his naked eyes. Then with an expression of interest he laid down his cigarette, and carrying the cane to the window, he looked over it again with a convex lens.

previous.content: Some people without possessing genius have a remarkable power of stimulating it. I confess, my dear fellow, that I am very much in your debt."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: He now took the stick from my hands and examined it for a few minutes with his naked eyes. Then with an expression of interest he laid down his cigarette, and carrying the cane to the window, he looked over it again with a convex lens.

next.content: "Interesting, though elementary," said he as he returned to his favourite corner of the settee. "There are certainly one or two indications upon the stick. It gives us the basis for several deductions."

previous.content: He had never said as much before, and I must admit that his words gave me keen pleasure, for I had often been piqued by his indifference to my admiration and to the attempts which I had made to give publicity to his methods. I was proud, too, to think that I had so far mastered his system as to apply it in a way which earned his approval.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Interesting, though elementary," said he as he returned to his favourite corner of the settee. "There are certainly one or two indications upon the stick. It gives us the basis for several deductions."

next.content: "Has anything escaped me?" I asked with some self-importance. "I trust that there is nothing of consequence which I have overlooked?"

previous.content: He now took the stick from my hands and examined it for a few minutes with his naked eyes. Then with an expression of interest he laid down his cigarette, and carrying the cane to the window, he looked over it again with a convex lens.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Has anything escaped me?" I asked with some self-importance. "I trust that there is nothing of consequence which I have overlooked?"

next.content: "I am afraid, my dear Watson, that most of your conclusions were erroneous. When I said that you stimulated me I meant, to be frank, that in noting your fallacies I was occasionally guided towards the truth. Not that you are entirely wrong in this instance. The man is certainly a country practitioner.

previous.content: "Interesting, though elementary," said he as he returned to his favourite corner of the settee. "There are certainly one or two indications upon the stick. It gives us the basis for several deductions."

content: And he walks a good deal."

next.content: "Then I was right."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "To that extent."

next.content: "But that was all."

previous.content: "Then I was right."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "But that was all."

next.content: "No, no, my dear Watson, not all—by no means all. I would suggest, for example, that a presentation to a doctor is more likely to come from a hospital than from a hunt, and that when the initials 'C.C.' are placed before that hospital the words 'Charing Cross' very naturally suggest themselves."

previous.content: "To that extent."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "No, no, my dear Watson, not all—by no means all. I would suggest, for example, that a presentation to a doctor is more likely to come from a hospital than from a hunt, and that when the initials 'C.C.' are placed before that hospital the words 'Charing Cross' very naturally suggest themselves."

next.content: "You may be right."

previous.content: "But that was all."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "You may be right."

next.content: "The probability lies in that direction. And if we take this as a working hypothesis we have a fresh basis from which to start our construction of this unknown visitor."

previous.content: "No, no, my dear Watson, not all—by no means all. I would suggest, for example, that a presentation to a doctor is more likely to come from a hospital than from a hunt, and that when the initials 'C.C.' are placed before that hospital the words 'Charing Cross' very naturally suggest themselves."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "The probability lies in that direction. And if we take this as a working hypothesis we have a fresh basis from which to start our construction of this unknown visitor."

next.content: "Well, then, supposing that 'C.C.H.' does stand for 'Charing Cross Hospital,' what further inferences may we draw?"

previous.content: "You may be right."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Well, then, supposing that 'C.C.H.' does stand for 'Charing Cross Hospital,' what further inferences may we draw?"

next.content: "Do none suggest themselves? You know my methods. Apply them!"

previous.content: "The probability lies in that direction. And if we take this as a working hypothesis we have a fresh basis from which to start our construction of this unknown visitor."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Do none suggest themselves? You know my methods. Apply them!"

next.content: "I can only think of the obvious conclusion that the man has practised in town before going to the country."

previous.content: "Well, then, supposing that 'C.C.H.' does stand for 'Charing Cross Hospital,' what further inferences may we draw?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I can only think of the obvious conclusion that the man has practised in town before going to the country."

next.content: "I think that we might venture a little farther than this. Look at it in this light. On what occasion would it be most probable that such a presentation would be made? When would his friends unite to give him a pledge of their good will? Obviously at the moment when Dr. Mortimer withdrew from the service of the hospital in order to start a practice for himself.

previous.content: "Do none suggest themselves? You know my methods. Apply them!"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I think that we might venture a little farther than this. Look at it in this light. On what occasion would it be most probable that such a presentation would be made? When would his friends unite to give him a pledge of their good will? Obviously at the moment when Dr. Mortimer withdrew from the service of the hospital in order to start a practice for himself.

next.content: We know there has been a presentation. We believe there has been a change from a town hospital to a country practice. Is it, then, stretching our inference too far to say that the presentation was on the occasion of the change?"

previous.content: "I can only think of the obvious conclusion that the man has practised in town before going to the country."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: We know there has been a presentation. We believe there has been a change from a town hospital to a country practice. Is it, then, stretching our inference too far to say that the presentation was on the occasion of the change?"

next.content: "It certainly seems probable."

previous.content: "I think that we might venture a little farther than this. Look at it in this light. On what occasion would it be most probable that such a presentation would be made? When would his friends unite to give him a pledge of their good will? Obviously at the moment when Dr. Mortimer withdrew from the service of the hospital in order to start a practice for himself.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "It certainly seems probable."

next.content: "Now, you will observe that he could not have been on the staff of the hospital, since only a man well-established in a London practice could hold such a position, and such a one would not drift into the country. What was he, then? If he was in the hospital and yet not on the staff he could only have been a house-surgeon or a house-physician—little more than a senior student.

previous.content: We know there has been a presentation. We believe there has been a change from a town hospital to a country practice. Is it, then, stretching our inference too far to say that the presentation was on the occasion of the change?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Now, you will observe that he could not have been on the staff of the hospital, since only a man well-established in a London practice could hold such a position, and such a one would not drift into the country. What was he, then? If he was in the hospital and yet not on the staff he could only have been a house-surgeon or a house-physician—little more than a senior student.

next.content: And he left five years ago—the date is on the stick. So your grave, middle-aged family practitioner vanishes into thin air, my dear Watson, and there emerges a young fellow under thirty, amiable, unambitious, absent-minded, and the possessor of a favourite dog, which I should describe roughly as being larger than a terrier and smaller than a mastiff.

previous.content: "It certainly seems probable."

content: And he left five years ago—the date is on the stick. previous.content: "Now, you will observe that he could not have been on the staff of the hospital, since only a man well-established in a London practice could hold such a position, and such a one would not drift into the country. What was he, then? If he was in the hospital and yet not on the staff he could only have been a house-surgeon or a house-physician—little more than a senior student.

next.content: I laughed incredulously as Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his settee and blew little wavering rings of smoke up to the ceiling.

previous.content: And he left five years ago—the date is on the stick. So your grave, middle-aged family practitioner vanishes into thin air, my dear Watson, and there emerges a young fellow under thirty, amiable, unambitious, absent-minded, and the possessor of a favourite dog, which I should describe roughly as being larger than a terrier and smaller than a mastiff.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: I laughed incredulously as Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his settee and blew little wavering rings of smoke up to the ceiling.

next.content: "As to the latter part, I have no means of checking you," said I, "but at least it is not difficult to find out a few particulars about the man's age and professional career." From my small medical shelf I took down the Medical Directory and turned up the name. There were several Mortimers, but only one who could be our visitor.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "As to the latter part, I have no means of checking you," said I, "but at least it is not difficult to find out a few particulars about the man's age and professional career." From my small medical shelf I took down the Medical Directory and turned up the name. There were several Mortimers, but only one who could be our visitor.

next.content: I read his record aloud.

previous.content: I laughed incredulously as Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his settee and blew little wavering rings of smoke up to the ceiling.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: I read his record aloud.

next.content: "No mention of that local hunt, Watson," said Holmes with a mischievous smile, "but a country doctor, as you very astutely observed. I think that I am fairly justified in my inferences. As to the adjectives, I said, if I remember right, amiable, unambitious, and absent-minded. It is my experience that it is only an amiable man in this world who receives testimonials, only an unambitious one who abandons a London career for the country, and only an absent-minded one who leaves his stick and not his visiting-card after waiting an hour in your room.

previous.content: "As to the latter part, I have no means of checking you," said I, "but at least it is not difficult to find out a few particulars about the man's age and professional career." From my small medical shelf I took down the Medical Directory and turned up the name. There were several Mortimers, but only one who could be our visitor.

As to the adjectives, I said, if I remember right, amiable, unambitious, and absent-minded. It is my experience that it is only an amiable man in this world who receives testimonials, only an unambitious one who abandons a London career for the country, and only an absent-minded one who leaves his stick and not his visiting-card after waiting an hour in your room.

next.content: "And the dog?"

previous.content: "No mention of that local hunt, Watson," said Holmes with a mischievous smile, "but a country doctor, as you very astutely observed. I think that I am fairly justified in my inferences. As to the adjectives, I said, if I remember right, amiable, unambitious, and absent-minded. It is my experience that it is only an amiable man in this world who receives testimonials, only an unambitious one who abandons a London career for the country, and only an absent-minded one who leaves his stick and not his visiting-card after waiting an hour in your room.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "And the dog?"

next.content: "Has been in the habit of carrying this stick behind his master. Being a heavy stick the dog has held it tightly by the middle, and the marks of his teeth are very plainly visible. The dog's jaw, as shown in the space between these marks, is too broad in my opinion for a terrier and not broad enough for a mastiff.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Has been in the habit of carrying this stick behind his master. Being a heavy stick the dog has held it tightly by the middle, and the marks of his teeth are very plainly visible. The dog's jaw, as shown in the space between these marks, is too broad in my opinion for a terrier and not broad enough for a mastiff.

next.content: It may have been—yes, by Jove, it is a curly-haired spaniel."

previous.content: "And the dog?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: It may have been—yes, by Jove, it is a curly-haired spaniel."

next.content: He had risen and paced the room as he spoke. Now he halted in the recess of the window. There was such a ring of conviction in his voice that I glanced up in surprise.

previous.content: "Has been in the habit of carrying this stick behind his master. Being a heavy stick the dog has held it tightly by the middle, and the marks of his teeth are very plainly visible. The dog's jaw, as shown in the space between these marks, is too broad in my opinion for a terrier and not broad enough for a mastiff.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: He had risen and paced the room as he spoke. Now he halted in the recess of the window. There was such a ring of conviction in his voice that I glanced up in surprise.

next.content: "My dear fellow, how can you possibly be so sure of that?"

previous.content: It may have been—yes, by Jove, it is a curly-haired spaniel."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "My dear fellow, how can you possibly be so sure of that?"

next.content: "For the very simple reason that I see the dog himself on our very door-step, and there is the ring of its owner. Don't move, I beg you, Watson. He is a professional brother of yours, and your presence may be of assistance to me. Now is the dramatic moment of fate, Watson, when you hear a step upon the stair which is walking into your life, and you know not whether for good or ill.

previous.content: He had risen and paced the room as he spoke. Now he halted in the recess of the window. There was such a ring of conviction in his voice that I glanced up in surprise.

content: "For the very simple reason that I see the dog himself on our very door-step, and there is the ring of its owner. Don't move, I beg you, Watson. He is a professional brother of yours, and your presence may be of assistance to me. Now is the dramatic moment of fate, Watson, when you hear a step upon the stair which is walking into your life, and you know not whether for good or ill.

next.content: What does Dr. James Mortimer, the man of science, ask of Sherlock Holmes, the specialist in crime? Come in!"

previous.content: "My dear fellow, how can you possibly be so sure of that?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: What does Dr. James Mortimer, the man of science, ask of Sherlock Holmes, the specialist in crime? Come in!"

next.content: The appearance of our visitor was a surprise to me, since I had expected a typical country practitioner. He was a very tall, thin man, with a long nose like a beak, which jutted out between two keen, gray eyes, set closely together and sparkling brightly from behind a pair of gold-rimmed glasses. He was clad in a professional but rather slovenly fashion, for his frock-coat was dingy and his trousers frayed.

previous.content: "For the very simple reason that I see the dog himself on our very door-step, and there is the ring of its owner. Don't move, I beg you, Watson. He is a professional brother of yours, and your presence may be of assistance to me. Now is the dramatic moment of fate, Watson, when you hear a step upon the stair which is walking into your life, and you know not whether for good or ill.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: The appearance of our visitor was a surprise to me, since I had expected a typical country practitioner. He was a very tall, thin man, with a long nose like a beak, which jutted out between two keen, gray eyes, set closely together and sparkling brightly from behind a pair of gold-rimmed glasses. He was clad in a professional but rather slovenly fashion, for his frock-coat was dingy and his trousers frayed.

next.content: Though young, his long back was already bowed, and he walked with a forward thrust of his head and a general air of peering benevolence. As he entered his eyes fell upon the stick in Holmes's hand, and he ran towards it with an exclamation of joy. "I am so very glad," said he. "I was not sure whether I had left it here or in the Shipping Office.

previous.content: What does Dr. James Mortimer, the man of science, ask of Sherlock Holmes, the specialist in crime? Come in!"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Though young, his long back was already bowed, and he walked with a forward thrust of his head and a general air of peering benevolence. As he entered his eyes fell upon the stick in Holmes's hand, and he ran towards it with an exclamation of joy. "I am so very glad," said he. "I was not sure whether I had left it here or in the Shipping Office.

next.content: I would not lose that stick for the world."

content: "Yes, sir."

next.content: "From Charing Cross Hospital?"

previous.content: "A presentation, I see," said Holmes.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "From Charing Cross Hospital?"

next.content: "From one or two friends there on the occasion of my marriage."

previous.content: "Yes, sir."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "From one or two friends there on the occasion of my marriage."

next.content: "Dear, dear, that's bad!" said Holmes, shaking his head.

previous.content: "From Charing Cross Hospital?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Dear, dear, that's bad!" said Holmes, shaking his head.

next.content: Dr. Mortimer blinked through his glasses in mild astonishment. "Why was it bad?"

previous.content: "From one or two friends there on the occasion of my marriage."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Dr. Mortimer blinked through his glasses in mild astonishment. "Why was it bad?"

next.content: "Only that you have disarranged our little deductions. Your marriage, you say?"

previous.content: "Dear, dear, that's bad!" said Holmes, shaking his head.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Only that you have disarranged our little deductions. Your marriage, you say?"

next.content: "Yes, sir. I married, and so left the hospital, and with it all hopes of a consulting practice. It was necessary to make a home of my own."

previous.content: Dr. Mortimer blinked through his glasses in mild astonishment. "Why was it bad?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Yes, sir. I married, and so left the hospital, and with it all hopes of a consulting practice. It was necessary to make a home of my own."

next.content: "Come, come, we are not so far wrong, after all," said Holmes. "And now, Dr. James Mortimer—"

previous.content: "Only that you have disarranged our little deductions. Your marriage, you say?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Come, come, we are not so far wrong, after all," said Holmes. "And now, Dr. James Mortimer—"

next.content: "Mister, sir, Mister—a humble M.R.C.S."

previous.content: "Yes, sir. I married, and so left the hospital, and with it all hopes of a consulting practice. It was necessary to make a home of my own."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Mister, sir, Mister—a humble M.R.C.S."

next.content: "And a man of precise mind, evidently."

previous.content: "Come, come, we are not so far wrong, after all," said Holmes. "And now, Dr. James Mortimer—"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "And a man of precise mind, evidently."

next.content: "A dabbler in science, Mr. Holmes, a picker up of shells on the shores of the great unknown ocean. I presume that it is Mr. Sherlock Holmes whom I am addressing and not—"

previous.content: "Mister, sir, Mister—a humble M.R.C.S."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "A dabbler in science, Mr. Holmes, a picker up of shells on the shores of the great unknown ocean. I presume that it is Mr. Sherlock Holmes whom I am addressing and not—"

next.content: "No, this is my friend Dr. Watson."

previous.content: "And a man of precise mind, evidently."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "No, this is my friend Dr. Watson."

next.content: "Glad to meet you, sir. I have heard your name mentioned in connection with that of your friend. You interest me very much, Mr. Holmes. I had hardly expected so dolichocephalic a skull or such well-marked supra-orbital development. Would you have any objection to my running my finger along your parietal fissure? A cast of your skull, sir, until the original is available, would be an ornament to any anthropological museum.

previous.content: "A dabbler in science, Mr. Holmes, a picker up of shells on the shores of the great unknown ocean. I presume that it is Mr. Sherlock Holmes whom I am addressing and not—"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Glad to meet you, sir. I have heard your name mentioned in connection with that of your friend. You interest me very much, Mr. Holmes. I had hardly expected so dolichocephalic a skull or such well-marked supra-orbital development. Would you have any objection to my running my finger along your parietal fissure? A cast of your skull, sir, until the original is available, would be an ornament to any anthropological museum.

next.content: It is not my intention to be fulsome, but I confess that I covet your skull."

previous.content: "No, this is my friend Dr. Watson."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: It is not my intention to be fulsome, but I confess that I covet your skull."

next.content: Sherlock Holmes waved our strange visitor into a chair. "You are an enthusiast in your line of thought, I perceive, sir, as I am in mine," said he. "I observe from your forefinger that you make your own cigarettes. Have no hesitation in lighting one."

previous.content: "Glad to meet you, sir. I have heard your name mentioned in connection with that of your friend. You interest me very much, Mr. Holmes. I had hardly expected so dolichocephalic a skull or such well-marked supra-orbital development. Would you have any objection to my running my finger along your parietal fissure? A cast of your skull, sir, until the original is available, would be an ornament to any anthropological museum.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Sherlock Holmes waved our strange visitor into a chair. "You are an enthusiast in your line of thought, I perceive, sir, as I am in mine," said he. "I observe from your forefinger that you make your own cigarettes. Have no hesitation in lighting one."

next.content: The man drew out paper and tobacco and twirled the one up in the other with surprising dexterity. He had long, quivering fingers as agile and restless as the antennae of an insect.

previous.content: It is not my intention to be fulsome, but I confess that I covet your skull."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: The man drew out paper and tobacco and twirled the one up in the other with surprising dexterity. He had long, quivering fingers as agile and restless as the antennae of an insect.

next.content: Holmes was silent, but his little darting glances showed me the interest which he took in our curious companion. "I presume, sir," said he at last, "that it was not merely for the purpose of examining my skull that you have done me the honour to call here last night and again today?"

previous.content: Sherlock Holmes waved our strange visitor into a chair. "You are an enthusiast in your line of thought, I perceive, sir, as I am in mine," said he. "I observe from your forefinger that you make your own cigarettes. Have no hesitation in lighting one."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: Holmes was silent, but his little darting glances showed me the interest which he took in our curious companion. "I presume, sir," said he at last, "that it was not merely for the purpose of examining my skull that you have done me the honour to call here last night and again today?"

next.content: "No, sir, no; though I am happy to have had the opportunity of doing that as well. I came to you, Mr. Holmes, because I recognized that I am myself an unpractical man and because I am suddenly confronted with a most serious and extraordinary problem. next.content: "Indeed, sir! May I inquire who has the honour to be the first?" asked Holmes with some asperity.

Recognizing, as I do, that you are the second hig

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Indeed, sir! May I inquire who has the honour to be the first?" asked Holmes with some asperity.

next.content: "To the man of precisely scientific mind the work of Monsieur Bertillon must always appeal strongly."

previous.content: hest expert in Europe—"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "To the man of precisely scientific mind the work of Monsieur Bertillon must always appeal strongly."

next.content: "Then had you not better consult him?"

previous.content: "Indeed, sir! May I inquire who has the honour to be the first?" asked Holmes with some asperity.

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Then had you not better consult him?"

next.content: "I said, sir, to the precisely scientific mind. But as a practical man of affairs it is acknowledged that you stand alone. I trust, sir, that I have not inadvertently—"

previous.content: "To the man of precisely scientific mind the work of Monsieur Bertillon must always appeal strongly."

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "I said, sir, to the precisely scientific mind. But as a practical man of affairs it is acknowledged that you stand alone. I trust, sir, that I have not inadvertently—"

next.content: "Just a little," said Holmes. "I think, Dr. Mortimer, you would do wisely if without more ado you would kindly tell me plainly what the exact nature of the problem is in which you demand my assistance."

previous.content: "Then had you not better consult him?"

author: By A. Conan Doyle
content: "Just a little," said Holmes. "I think, Dr. Mortimer, you would do wisely if without more ado you would kindly tell me plainly what the exact nature of the problem is in which you demand my assistance."
